Name: This War of Mine: Rubble Die
Description: In the game’s mechanics this Rubble Die represents a decision to sacrifice some time while searching through a location. We risk more than usual but instead we can find something more. You roll the die. In most cases the roll will mean one of the more probable results but from time to time a very hard VERY HARD to get result will be rolled and with it we will trigger an extremely rare finding or an event.
Families: Game: This War of Mine (Awaken Realms)

Name: Artillerie vor!
Description:
Each player has 13 infantry companies, 2 light batteries and one heavy battery. At the beginning of the game, the pieces are set up on the red, blue and yellow marked spaces. Each turn the players move 2 of their pieces 1 space in any direction. The infantry has a firing range of 1 space, the light batteries of 2 space and the heavy batteries of 2 and 3 spaces. A piece is destroyed if it is in the firing range of 3 enemy pieces. If a piece is at one of the two fortified spaces, it has to be in the firing range of 4 enemy pieces. If a player has less than 4 pieces left, he has lost the game.

—user summary

Name: Autobörse
Description:
The players move their pawns around the board and buy and sell used and new cars. On some spaces the players win or lose money. After a prearranged time the player with the most money and cars wins the game.

—user summary

Name: Kaedama: A Ramen Story
Description:
In Kaedama, you and a partner are new restaurant owners looking to spread the universal joy of ramen. You must manage customers, assemble bowls of ramen, and make enough money to someday buy the restaurant of your dreams.

In this 2 player co-operative game, one player is in charge of the 'Back of House' responsible for prepping and cooking food as well as washing dishes and plating. The other player controls the 'Front of House' by seating customers, upselling drinks & appetizers, and entertaining the guests. Each round, players will roll action dice to determine what actions they can take. However, in order to take an action, it must be paired with a limited pool of speed dice. You'll need to communicate and strategize on how best to use manage your time.

Be quick about it! No one likes a cold bowl of soup!

—description from the publisher

Name: Arkham Horror: The Card Game – Dim Carcosa: Mythos Pack
Description:
Dim Carcosa is the sixth and final Mythos Pack in The Path to Carcosa cycle for Arkham Horror: The Card Game.

Your investigation into the mysterious play The King in Yellow has led you across the globe and brought you to the edge of madness. Now, in the final act of The Path to Carcosa you travel beyond the cosmos to a world a place beyond all imagining. Before you lies a warped, alien city. Its twisting streets and aberrant architecture have no semblance of order or structure. In the distance, a murky lake reflects the glare of two suns. This is Carcosa–the realm of madness in the stars, where Hastur reigns supreme.

All shall be revealed when you travel to Dim Carcosa, meaning that the locations in this scenario have no unrevealed side. Instead, their reverse sides bear story cards to push your plotlines forward to their final curtain. In this lost realm, insanity is inevitable. But even with your mind fractured and broken, your investigation does not end here. In Dim Carcosa, you are not defeated when you have horror equal to or greater than your sanity. Instead, you journey on, facing impossible odds in the hopes to return home alive.

—description from the publisher
Families: Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: Arkham Horror – The Card Game
Game: Arkham Horror TCG – The Path to Carcosa
Series: Arkham Horror Files (Fantasy Flight Games)

Name: Interpoly/Kuddelmuddel
Description:
Interpoly (2 player)
One player has 16 red pawns (policemen), the other player has 4 yellow pawns (gangsters). Movement is determined by a die. Red may share the die result between two or more pawns. The police tries to enclose the gangsters and the gangsters try to escape to the 4 home spaces in the corners of the game board. On the roll of a 6 red may roll again, yellow may take 1 red pawn off the board. 1 captured policeman counts 1 point, 1 enclosed gangster counts 2 points. After the game, the players switch their roles and after 2 games the player with the most points wins.

Kuddelmuddel (2 or more player)
4 red pawns are placed in the center of the game board, the rest are placed near the board. The destination spaces are marked with the letters A-F. Each player is assigned to one destination space. Movement is determined by a die. Each player may move any pawn. If he gets one on his destination space he keeps that pawn and places a new one in the center space.
The player who gets the most pawns to his destination space wins the game.

—user summary

Name: Darkmace
Description:
Darkmace is a 2-4 players miniatures board game about dark ages' wars. You will control one of four armies aiming to conquer the most territory in the battle field. The types of combat units are infantry, archer, cavalry and catapult each having different moving, attacking and defending abilities. You must position them strategically across the battlefield to best coordinate your attacks and to enlarge your land.

Darkmace is played over 13 turns, with each turn consisting of move units, recruit units, construct buildings and manage gold steps. At the end of the last turn, the player that controls the most provinces is declared as the winner.

Darkmace combines miniature gaming and area control styles on one board. You must best position your units individually on hex spaces while taking the control of the provinces as a whole.

—description from the publisher

Name: Last Blood
Description:
Last Blood is a turn based competitive or cooperative thriller where players explore, fight and run from monsters.  The game features exciting events and a very unique computer based art style.

The game is largely based on exploration and encounters with monsters.  A very simplistic combat and movement system allows fast play but with complex choices.

Players lose health from combat, starvation and poison.  The last player alive wins.

—description from the publisher

Name: Eight Cards
Description:
Eight Cards is a game where 2-4 explorers (players) go on an expedition for 7 days (turns) to try and earn the most reputation (points) and become the most legendary explorer (the winner).

Gameplay is simple to learn and play, but always changing and near impossible to predict. It works like this:

All players have 8 cards. These 8 cards are the same 8 cards as everybody else has in their hands. Each turn the players select a card and once everyone has selected their card, the cards are revealed at the same time and compared. Depending on the number of people who played the card, the outcome changes. Based on the number of players with the same card, positive outcomes can become negative, the target of the card may change and even special actions must be performed.

As the head of your expedition, your role is to figure out when others will play each card, bluff about when you're going to play your cards, and deduct when it's safest to play your cards based on what's been played already.

It's a game of reason, strategy and sometimes just plain luck to figure out how to build the best reputation and win the game.

—description from the publisher

Name: Rabbit Trails: The Play on Words Game
Description:
What is Rabbit Trails? Rabbit Trails is card game for all ages (especially students!) involving play with word association.

How do you play it? Play starts with each player being dealt 7 cards. Then the top card of the remaining deck is flipped over. Each player takes turns laying a card this is easily associated with the card showing. For example: The card flipped at the start of the game is, "Rabbit". Player 1 plays, "Carrot" (because rabbits eat carrots). Player 2 plays, "Chef" (because chefs can cook carrots). Player 3 plays, "Astronaut" (because both chef and astronaut are professions). And player 4 plays, "Grape". Wait! Grape?? Grape clearly doesn't match with "Astronaut". The other players hear out Player 4's reasoning and vote on whether or not to allow the card to stay in play. They vote for the card to be removed. Player 4 has to draw a new card as a penalty and play continues. The winner is the first person to get rid of all their cards. If a player cannot play (and does not want to try and fool the others by playing a less than perfect card), the player can draw and, if the card will work, play it right away.

But that's not all! There are also action cards featuring various ways to foil the plans of the other players and get you closer to winning the game.

What are the benefits of Rabbit Trails? Benefit #1, Rabbit Trails is an awesome game. Seriously! I have been designing this game over the past couple of years and have been getting bogged down with requests to make this game available from friends, family, and even people who see us playing it while out around town. After refining the cards and getting the rules nailed down, this game is finally ready for prime time! But that isn't all... Benefit #2, is related to education. It's not often that fun and education go together, but Rabbit Trails bridges that gap. Because the aim of the game is to get players to find connections between words, it makes students use higher order thinking, like analysis and evaluation to be successful, which are at the top of Bloom's taxonomy.Benefit #3 [Bonus], Rabbit Trails is great to test your English language skills if you are currently learning English or use English as a second language. It makes English language learners think critically about words and their multiple meanings!

—description from the publisher

Name: Pokémon TCG: Dragon Blast/Dragon Blade Expansion
Wrath of Kings: House Nasier – Firehawk Reavers
Description:
Only the most elite of Ashmen graduate into the mighty Firehawk Reaver squads. Dedicated assault specialists, Firehawks turn in their duelist’s blades for deadly war tridents to become the spearhead of House Nasier offensives.

—description from the publisher
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Wrath of Kings: House Goritsi – Gotha Knights
Description: The most honorable soldiers dedicated to House Goritsi, the monstrous Gotha Knights bring a new stalwart refusal to yield against any number of foes. Once the werewolves dig in their clawed feet, their deathcleavers bring a swift demise to those who test them.

Name: Wrath of Kings: House Shael Han – Paragons of Wrath
Description: Shael Han has summoned forth the embodiment of theheavenly Childreninto the armored forms of the Paragonsof Wrath. Filled with celestial fire and armed with theunderstanding of an enlightened path, they protect theHouse selflesslywith devotion, and without complaint.

Name: Wrath of Kings: House Goritsi – Whitemane Duelists
Description: Fast and merciless with their flashing blade, the WhitemaneDuelists of House Goritsiare battlefield assassins of the highestdegree. Once they get the scent of their quarry, nothing willstand in the way ofthem wetting their sword with its blood.

Name: Wrath of Kings: House Shael Han – Dragon Lancers
Description: The Dragon Lancers of the enlightened House of Shael Han are, once inducted into their elite ranks, are given ancient armor and spears that have been steeped in the essence of the great Celestial Dragons. Clad in the spiritual essence of dragons, the Lancers are fast, tireless, and lethal.

Name: 5-Minute Dragon Slayer
Description:
Solitaire, print and play game. The Hero must inflict 8 wounds on the dragon before the dragon inflicts 4 wounds on the Hero.

The board shows the body of the dragon, divided in boxes with target numbers in them. The player places Aim cubes to indicate the area the Hero is targeting, and rolls dice. An aim cube must be removed to reroll the dice, narrowing the area that can be hit.

After rolling, the player uses the dice to attack the dragon and/or cast spells.

Next, the player rolls to determine the type of attack the dragon will perform, and resolves that attack.

The game continues until either the Hero or the dragon is dead. It *is* possible that they will both die in the same turn, ending the game in a tragic tie.

—description from the publisher

Name: Tracks on Mars
Description:
Early colonization efforts of Mars have been successful. With dozens of outposts scattered across the surface, a new challenge awaits: providing infrastructure to the red planet and moving goods to where they are needed most (while making a tidy profit of course). Fortunately the abundance of precious metals will help with this task by allowing upgrades to the transport vessels over time.

Tracks on Mars is a light-weight family crayon rail game. It has been designed specifically for two players. Drawing the tracks, loading goods onto the pawns, and over sized dice all work together to make this a very tactile experience. Luck is a major factor but can be mitigated by re-rolls and catch-up mechanics. On a strategic level, players have to balance network building, transportation, and equipment upgrades.

The core mechanics are Yahtzee-style dice rolling and resource allocation. Matching dice rolls are converted to currency which is then used to either claim new routes or move the player's pawns to pick up and deliver goods. Victory points are ultimately  scored depending on the distance that goods have been transported. Players have to decide whether they want to make multiple short runs for few VPs or spend turns building a long route for fewer high value transports.

This is a print & play title comprised of five dice, 40 resource cubes, currency token cards, an 18" x 18" board, and four 3D printed pawns.

—description from the designer

Name: Pokémon TCG: Starter Pack Expansion
Description:
User summary

Starter Pack - ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒ‘ãƒƒ is a Japanese-language expansion roughly corresponding to the contemporaneous English-language expansion Generations.

The expansion includes 72 cards.

Unlike regular expansions, Generations booster packs could not be purchased individually from booster boxes. Instead, they were only available in special 20th Anniversary-related items of merchandise, which included Mythical Pokémon Collections and Red & Blue Collections. Each Mythical Pokémon Collection comes packaged with 2 Generations packs, in addition to a special Full Art promotional card and collector's pin featuring 1 of the 11 Mythical Pokémon available as part of the 20th Anniversary distributions during 2016.

The Japanese Starter Pack emulates the original both in terms of design and the random nature of the cards included. While the cards contained in each deck can vary, they are grouped based on evolutionary family and type. The deck can be broken down into two sections, which are packaged separately. The first section will always contain one of two Mega Pokémon, either M Venusaur-EX or M Charizard-EX, in addition to a fixed selection of Pokémon and Energy cards relative to its type, plus multiples of Trainer cards for a total of 27 cards. The second section contains 3 different groups of Pokémon containing an evolutionary family of 1 type, plus 1 other Pokémon of the same type, matching Energy cards, and a selection of single Trainer cards for a total of 33 cards. None of the cards available as part of the pack have rarity symbols. A special Blastoise version of the Starter Pack (Japanese: ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ¼ã‚¿ãƒ¼ãƒ‘ãƒƒã‚¯ ã‚«ãƒ¡ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚¹ver.) was later made available, initially exclusive to venues hosting the Kamex Mega Battle in Japan during May 2016, followed by a more general release from the Pokémon Center Online store in June 2016. This version substitutes the Grass or Fire-type cards available in the first section of the regular version with Water-type cards. These cards appear in the core Generations set, but are classed as secret cards in the Starter Pack. The Starter Pack also comes with an exclusive Chansey coin.

-- user summary obtained from: https://leonhartopedia.fandom.com/wiki/Generations_(TCG)

Name: Pokémon TCG: Ultra Sun/Ultra Moon Expansion
Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Technology Starter Deck
Description:
Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey is a new take on the collectible non-collectible KB line, with Jeffrey Neil Bellinger once again putting the rabbits through the grinder. Six new starter decks Animals, Crops, Elementals, Energy, Land and Technology will be available, and players can construct personalized decks of no less than 60 cards, with the cards from any deck.

Ultimate Odyssey is not collectible or random. Players can now buy starter decks and booster expansions for Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey and then use any combination of those cards to form their own constructed decks to play against opponents. Unlike in Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot, where up to eight players play with the same deck of cards, all sharing the same draw pile, Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey has players each draw only from their own constructed deck of 60 cards. There are not any random packs, so players will always know which cards they are purchasing in a deck and they can buy the right products for their planned deck. For Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey six brand new starter decks (red, violet, blue, yellow, green, or orange) allow players to construct a personalized deck with any of the cards of any deck.

The setting for the new game is an ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth. Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

Name: Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Land Starter Deck
Description:

The setting for the new game is an ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth. Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

The Red deck has an Energy based theme which also includes power, invisible forces, and extraordinary cards such as Gone In Twelve Seconds which can destroy a city and Death Delay which allows your bunny to live past its time!

Name: Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Elementals Starter Deck
Description:
Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey is a new take on the collectible non-collectible KB line, with Jeffrey Neil Bellinger once again putting the rabbits through the grinder. Six new starter decks Animals, Crops, Elementals, Energy, Land and Technology will be available, and players can construct personalized decks of no less than 60 cards, with the cards from any deck.

Ultimate Odyssey is not collectible or random. Players can now buy starter decks and booster expansions for Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey and then use any combination of those cards to form their own constructed decks to play against opponents. Unlike in Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot, where up to eight players play with the same deck of cards, all sharing the same draw pile, Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey has players each draw only from their own constructed deck of 60 cards. There are not any random packs, so players will always know which cards they are purchasing in a deck and they can buy the right products for their planned deck. For Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey six brand new starter decks (red, violet, blue, yellow, green, or orange) allow players to construct a personalized deck with any of the cards of any deck.

The setting for the new game is an ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth. Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

The Violet deck has an Elemental based theme which also includes metals, jewels and amazing cards such as Slow Smelting which causes players to lose their turn and Maybe, Maybe Not which can eliminate an opponent’s attack!

Name: Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Crops Starter Deck
Description:
Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey is a new take on the collectible non-collectible KB line, with Jeffrey Neil Bellinger once again putting the rabbits through the grinder. Six new starter decks Animals, Crops, Elementals, Energy, Land and Technology will be available, and players can construct personalized decks of no less than 60 cards, with the cards from any deck.

Ultimate Odyssey is not collectible or random. Players can now buy starter decks and booster expansions for Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey and then use any combination of those cards to form their own constructed decks to play against opponents. Unlike in Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot, where up to eight players play with the same deck of cards, all sharing the same draw pile, Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey has players each draw only from their own constructed deck of 60 cards. There are not any random packs, so players will always know which cards they are purchasing in a deck and they can buy the right products for their planned deck. For Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey six brand new starter decks (red, violet, blue, yellow, green, or orange) allow players to construct a personalized deck with any of the cards of any deck.

The setting for the new game is an ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth. Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

The Green deck has a Crops based theme which also includes fruits, vegetables and marvelous cards such as Transplanted Troop which allows players to steal bunnies and Reversal Of Order which helps dictate the order of card play.

Name: Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Animals Starter Deck
Description:
Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey is a new take on the collectible non-collectible KB line, with Jeffrey Neil Bellinger once again putting the rabbits through the grinder. Six new starter decks Animals, Crops, Elementals, Energy, Land and Technology will be available, and players can construct personalized decks of no less than 60 cards, with the cards from any deck.

Ultimate Odyssey is not collectible or random. Players can now buy starter decks and booster expansions for Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey and then use any combination of those cards to form their own constructed decks to play against opponents. Unlike in Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot, where up to eight players play with the same deck of cards, all sharing the same draw pile, Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey has players each draw only from their own constructed deck of 60 cards. There are not any random packs, so players will always know which cards they are purchasing in a deck and they can buy the right products for their planned deck. For Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey six brand new starter decks (red, violet, blue, yellow, green, or orange) allow players to construct a personalized deck with any of the cards of any deck.

The setting for the new game is an ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth. Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

Name: Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Lively and Spry
Description:
Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey is a new take on the collectible non-collectible KB line, with Jeffrey Neil Bellinger once again putting the rabbits through the grinder. Six new starter decks Animals, Crops, Elementals, Energy, Land and Technology will be available, and players can construct personalized decks of no less than 60 cards, with the cards from any deck.

Ultimate Odyssey is not collectible or random. Players can now buy starter decks and booster expansions for Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey and then use any combination of those cards to form their own constructed decks to play against opponents. Unlike in Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot, where up to eight players play with the same deck of cards, all sharing the same draw pile, Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey has players each draw only from their own constructed deck of 60 cards. There are not any random packs, so players will always know which cards they are purchasing in a deck and they can buy the right products for their planned deck. For Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey six brand new starter decks (red, violet, blue, yellow, green, or orange) allow players to construct a personalized deck with any of the cards of any deck.

The setting for the new game is an ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth. Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

Lively and Spry contains the Animals, Crops, and Land starter decks, as well as 3 limited edition promo cards.

Name: Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey: Heroic and Azoic
Description:
Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey is a new take on the collectible non-collectible KB line, with Jeffrey Neil Bellinger once again putting the rabbits through the grinder. Six new starter decks Animals, Crops, Elementals, Energy, Land and Technology will be available, and players can construct personalized decks of no less than 60 cards, with the cards from any deck.

Ultimate Odyssey is not collectible or random. Players can now buy starter decks and booster expansions for Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey and then use any combination of those cards to form their own constructed decks to play against opponents. Unlike in Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot, where up to eight players play with the same deck of cards, all sharing the same draw pile, Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey has players each draw only from their own constructed deck of 60 cards. There are not any random packs, so players will always know which cards they are purchasing in a deck and they can buy the right products for their planned deck. For Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey six brand new starter decks (red, violet, blue, yellow, green, or orange) allow players to construct a personalized deck with any of the cards of any deck.

The setting for the new game is an ultimate race to build a bunny society on planet Earth. Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey pits players against each other as they struggle to gain Civilization Points, by building cities and increasing their bunny populations. Players gain points by developing their own civilizations or by using zany weapons and hilarious scenarios to destroy their opponents.

Heroic and Azoic contains the Elementals, Energy, and Technology starter decks, as well as 3 limited edition promo cards.

Name: Flight of Pollen
Description:
When a tree is old enough, it starts to make flowers. The flower is a message from the tree to you, the pollinators. Calling you to come by day and by night – to drink its nectar, to pick up its pollen grains, and to transport these to another tree of the same species. Because it’s ready to breed.

Flight of Pollen is a semi-cooperative game where you pollinate as many trees as possible by visiting them with a variety of different New Zealand pollinators, with different pollinators being more successful under different weather conditions.  Rounds are split into day and night segments, with different pollinators active during the day versus the night.  Each pollinator must move from one plant to the next of the same species, moving pollen between them until all of the plants of the target species are pollinated- if any are missed, the game is lost.  One or more different native New Zealand plant are the focus for each of the four rounds, and as the rounds progress more pollinator species are added, as well as more plant species with more challenging pollination requirements.  If all of the required plants have been pollinated, then the team that collected the most berries wins the game.

Over each of the four levels different trees send out differing messages in their flowers. You’ll need to work together to complete each level, moving as the elements allow.

As flowers pollinated by you (or the wind) become seeds or berries, teams can collect the resulting berries.

Locally made, with recycled materials and FSC card

Name: Trollz: Magic of the 5 Game
Description:
Welcome to the Trollz World! Join the Best Friends for Life as they scoot all around Trollzopolis collecting Gem tokens. But watch out for Snarf--Simon's half dog, half ogre sidekick--or he'll slow down your quest to defeat Simon!

To get around, players roll a die. Pimple Spell spaces and Snarf spaces can limit players' movement but can be gotten around with Obsidian tokens and Obsidian Spell Phone tokens, which can reroll dice or use the spell phone instead of rolling. Other spaces can call every player to a specific space. The Spell Phone included with the game decides what happens when it's landed on or rolled via a text message that appears on the screen.

The objective is to be the first player to collect all 5 Gem tokens and defeat Simon in the final showdown.

Based on the Trollz toyline and cartoon by DiC Entertainment.

Name: 5-Minute Hydra Slayer
Description:
A sequel to 5-Minute Dragon Slayer. This time, a 4-headed hydra is attacking your peaceful fantasy town!

Solitaire game. Each turn you choose 2 adjacent areas on the body of the monster to target, and roll dice. If you want to reroll you must remove one of your possible target areas, or lower your armor value by 1. Then you use your rolled dice to attack a part of the monster you were targeting, or to activate a spell.

Next, a die roll is used to determine which attack the hydra uses against you, and a second die roll to resolve that attack.

Continue until you kill the hydra, or the hydra kills your hero.

Name: Downforce: Danger Circuit
Description:
Downforce: Danger Circuit, an expansion for Downforce, consists of two new tracks on a double-sided game board as well as six new racer powers to shuffle with those in the base game.

Switchback Pass presents dangerous spaces. Cars may move through such spaces only to pass other cars and may not end their turn on one. Crosstown Speedway features two crossover loops, where cars in the rear can block cars ahead of them, and split areas of the track, where players must choose between the shorter single-lane section or the longer, more wide open section.

New powers are:

     Tough - On any player's turn, move 2 additional spaces when your car ends its movement next to a rumble strip (red-and-white).
     Bold - On your turn, if your car would move 1 or 2 spaces, move it 3 spaces instead.
     Defensive - If none of your cars move on your turn, move one of your cars 3 spaces.
     Reckless - On your turn, if your car moves diagonally between two adjacent cars, move it 2 additional spaces.
     Experienced - If any car starts its movement directly ahead of your car, move your car into the space they moved out of.
     Ambitious - On any player's turn, if your car crosses a betting line, move it 2 additional spaces.
Families: Series: Auto Racing card system (Wolfgang Kramer)

Name: 5 Stack
Description:
5 Stack is an exciting chip stacking game with the perfect mixture of strategy and chance. 5 Stack is simple enough that a 5-year-old can play it and interesting enough to captivate the seasoned board game veteran.  Proudly made in the USA, components include a game board, coloured wooden chips, dice, scoring pad, and instructions.  Designed by Jackson Robinson, and published by Kings Wild Project.

To set-up: Players all get 25 chips in their colour plus a single gold coin, and dice are rolled for a random set-up that adds five chips per player to a 6x6 game-board.

To play: In clockwise order players take turns to: (a) move a chip or a chip stack of their colour in a straight direction on the board; (b) place a new chip with the location determined by a dice roll. The game ends when someone has played all their chips and cleared all chip stacks under their control.

To win: The aim of the game is to score the highest number of points.  Points are scored by clearing a stack (when a stack under your control reaches 5 or more chips, with gold chips being worth 5 instead of 1 point each).  Your final score is the total number of "cleared" chips minus any of your unplayed and uncleared chips at game end.

Name: Star Wars: Feel the Force
Description:
Welcome brave fighters fighting for the freedom of the Rebellion! Another task is waiting for you. You have to decode the secret code which you received from the command and you must obtain secret information about Frist Order’s plans. 
In the game you will be playing  as Rey, Poe, Finn and Rose. Who will be the first to complete the mission? May the force be with you!

The goal of the game is to collect three white and three black information markers. At the moment when the first player puts the last of the six markers on his/hers  the character board, the game ends immediately and the player wins the game.

Each round of the game is divided into two parts: coding and gaining information. In the first part, players set up their code as quickly as possible to determine in what order players will take turns and how many actions they will have. In the second part, they do as much actions as they get after the first round: you can move your pawn, explore squares, rotate them, and gain information markers.

—description from the designer

Name: Zauberei hoch drei: Zusatz-Zauber
Description:
This is a set of two new enchantments for Zauberei hoch drei. It was available at SPIEL'17 as a single card; the two tokens have to be cut out.

The new enchantments are:

     Tarnkappe ("Magic hat"): If you are on the stairs, your teammates can still help you this turn.
     Zauberkugel ("Magic Ball"): All Lumies revealed this turn will remain face-up until the end of the game.

Name: Emojical Mau-Mau
Description:
Now play Crazy Eights crazier than ever!

Playing cards with numbers are history. In this new interpretation of Crazy Eights, emojis are the name of the game. Who will be the first to shed all their cards and win the game? Emojical Mau-Mau contains completely new and crazy action cards which put additional spice in the game. "Donating" and "Gambling" cards will drive your fellow players crazy – and get you on your way to victory.

Easy to learn rules - Quick game start - Great fun for the whole family!

—description from the publisher

Name: Соображарий Junior (Think it Up! Junior)
Description:
Who will be the first and say some animal with "L"? Maybe the toothiest thing in the world with "S"? Or 3 things with "T" that is drawing in water?

Think it Up! Junior is famous party games for the little ones and contains task that will be understood by children.

—description from the publisher

Name: Living Planet: Industria
Description:
In your efforts to exploit the riches of the Living Planet, you may find yourself in the midst of an industrial revolution. In this expansion you will find:
 20 x   pipelines
  4 x   Electricity Storage Units
  4 x   Pharmacological research units
  4 x   Oil Refineries
  4 x   Stell Foundries
  4 x   Weaponry Research Units 
  2 x   Industria Map Tiles 
  1 x   Rule booklet

Name: Battle of the Numbers
Description:
At the beginning of the game, each opponent rolls the general/captain and places him in the captain’s area(Three circles). Then place the tie breaker die(clear with a small blue die inside it) in the tiebreaker area(5 circles) To start out each player rolls 2 of their dice and places them in the first row. Then the player can choose to either keep his/her row and try his/her luck or they can lower a die’s number by one and roll another die. The objective is to have a higher sum for each row than your opponent. The max capacity for each row is five die. At the end of the turn both players add up the die and the larger number is subtracted from the lower number. Next the Difference is taken away from the losing army. If a tie is to occur then the clear die with a blue die in it is rolled by each player and the sum of the two die is added to each player’s side based on the roll. Keep doing this until there is no tie. If you have a one in your row at the end of a turn change the one to a six before you add up. If you end up calculating before changing the one to a six the one stays a one for the remainder of the game. If you lose then you can roll the 20 sided die and re roll the captain. Place the same number of added die to your side of the military and try to beat your opponent.

Things to remember: 

     If you roll a one with your general, it stays a one
     Lower each die one at a time
     The game stops after you completely lose all of your die and roll the failure die


—description from the designer

Name: Living Planet: Aquarius
Description:
Our explorers finally discovered that there is a high stakes to explore MYC.14.250’s seas. This expansion adds new possibilities, beyond lands... With a new vehicle and a new movement rule come more diversity and new strategies to master! You can now construct 3 new buildings (Oil rigs, Offshore Windturbines and Hydroelectric generators) and exploit rare Vibranium Mines hidden on some islands. Sail using the winds for free, or using an Oil and a movement action to go wherever you want (of course, within the movement limits). Oil becomes then an essential resource.

To perform an Explore action, you will either draw in the Land map tile pile or in the new Sea map tile pile. But beware, don’t expect a calm sea. A new cataclysm shows up you can’t protect yourself from: the Tsunami! Do not forget raging Tornadoes still there to knock you down… Careful! Discovering new horizons may be risky!

—description from the publisher

Name: Living Planet: Arboria
Description:
Arboria brings its own novelties, and a strong theme! This expansion is fully compatible with the two previous ones: Aquarius and Industria!

Arboria Expansion provides a new resource to exploit. Wood! But, as everything seems unusual on this planet, these trees are special… The sap they contain can be sold a fortune back on Earth. Burnt in a stove, it is twice more efficient than best wood you could use! And finally, travel time to bring it back to Earth allows its optimal drying! Here a sixth way to make rich!

Wood is a rare resource here. There will be less wood than the other resources. Cutting wood is pretty easy, sawmill produces wood on 2 die values. Watch out! Shortage and Market crash will occur more frequently…

Woods are thick and vehicles can’t move in… Furthermore, this wood is nearly impossible to extinguish when set on fire. A new cataclysm shows up: Forest Fires. Ferocious and brutal, they are only triggered in woods. Scientists didn’t find any solution to protect yourself from them.

Arboria also includes two special buldings: Botanical Research Centers and Shipyards to be used respectively in combination with Industria and Aquarius Expansions.

—description from the publisher

Name: Baby
Description:
Baby is cooperative deduction micro game for two to three players in which one player facilitates the recurring and semi-random needs of the infant whilst the other one (or two) player(s) take on the role of the parents, attempting to decipher and resolve the cause of their child's cries.

The game consists of three micro decks of five cards each. One deck represents a happy baby, another a sad baby, and the middle a neutral baby. A baby status token moves between the decks, indicating the current climate of the infant and also defining from which deck the next card should be drawn. Cards are only seen by the player playing the role of the child, and upon them are depicted up to two different needs of the five in the game: hungry, poopie, sleepy, restless and crying wolf (ie. nothing's really wrong). Depending on the card the player will then place face-down tokens showing the baby is upset but not visibly indicating what the cause is. These needs can be resolved with different parent tokens, such as feeding, diapers, carrying, music and playing. While the need tokens don't come in multiples and therefore can't "double up" on the same time the parents only have a limited number of each of their tokens so they must use them wisely. After each step of the game (child expressing and then parents attempting to solve it) the baby status is always move to indicate the new state of the child. If a card should be drawn from an empty deck, the game has ended and the players all win if the status of the baby is happy.

Name: Unstable Unicorns: Kickstarter Exclusive Cards
Description:
This pack contains 5 cards exclusive to the Kickstarter campaign.

The cards are to be added to the base game.

The Proudest Unicorn
"When this card enters your Stable, each player must give you a card from their hand."

Eternal Youth Unicorn
"If this card is in your Stable at the beginning of your turn, replace a Unicorn in any player's stable with a Baby Unicorn. The replaced Unicorn goes to the Discard Pile.""

Legendary Flying Unicorn
"When this card enters your Stable, each player must DISCARD a card. If this card is sacrificed or destroyed, return it to your hand."

Unicorn of the Cosmos
"When this card enters your Stable, shuffle each player's hand and the discard pile into the deck. Each player must then DRAW five cards."

The Horniest Unicorn
"If this card is in your stable at the beginning of your turn, you may move a Unicorn from any player's stable to your Stable. At the end of your turn, move the Unicorn back to it's original stable."

Name: Steamroller: Tannenberg 1914
Description:
"Steamroller" is a highly playable, tense, operational look at 1914's pivotal Tannenberg campaign. Command either the German 8th Army or the Russian 1st and 2nd Armies in the battle that decided the early course of the Great War on the Eastern Front. The game is the latest iteration of the system used in Hermann's earlier "Race to the Sea 1914", (as well as "Dead Reckoning") with corps, divisions, and brigades traipsing around the wilderlands of East Prussia and northeastern Poland.

Game components include one 11 x 17 game map, one sheet of 88 die-cut counters, and an array of cards used to bid for initiative and determine combat results.

Name: Blood Bowl (2016 Edition): Orc Team Card Pack
Description:
This is a pack of handy reference cards for an Orc Blood Bowl team, along with blank cards allowing every coach to create their own players! Contained in the pack:


     Reference cards for Goblins, Throwers, Blitzers, Black Orc Blockers and Trolls;
     Reference cards for the following star players: Scrappa Sorehead, Ripper Bolgrot, The Black Gobbo;
     The following blank cards that you can use to create your own players: 8 Linemen, 5 Goblins, 3 Throwers, 5 Blitzers, 5 Black Orc Blockers, 2 Trolls;
     A team roster card, with match record on the reverse;
     5 Special Play cards: Spear Chukka, Shamanic Ju Ju, Unforgiving Fans, Fungus Brew, Squigeon Away;
     The most important card: a card explaining how to use the other cards. 


—description from the publisher

Name: Blood Bowl (2016 Edition): Human Team Card Pack
Description:
This is a pack of handy reference cards for a Human Blood Bowl team, along with blank cards allowing every coach to create their own players! Contained in the pack:


     Reference cards for Linemen, Catchers, Throwers, Blitzers and Ogres;
     Reference cards for the following star players: Morg 'N' Thorg, Helmut Wulf, Karla Von Kill;
     The following blank cards that you can use to create your own players: 9 Linemen, 6 Catchers, 3 Throwers, 6 Blitzers, 2 Ogres;
     A team roster card, with match record on the reverse;
     8 Special Play cards: Mercenary Meteormancer, Experimental Footgear, The Protegé, Bad Burger, Rowdy Wizard, Hungry Griffon, Steelhelm's Sporting Tonic, The Latest Techniques.
     The most important card: a card explaining how to use the other cards.

Name: Blood Bowl (2016 Edition): Elven Union Team Card Pack
Description:
This is a pack of handy reference cards for an Elven Union Bowl team, along with blank cards allowing every coach to create their own players! Contained in the pack:


     Reference cards for Linemen, Throwers, Blitzers and Catchers;
     Reference cards for the following Star Players: Eldril Sidewinder, Lucien Swift, Valen Swift and Jordell Freshbreeze;
     The following blank cards that you can use to create your own players:10 Linemen, 4 Throwers, 4 Blitzers and 6 Catchers;
     A team roster card, with match record on the reverse;
     The following 5 Special Play Random Events cards: Enjoy your trip?, Ref's Favourite, Martial Training, Enforcer and Quick Thinking;
     The following 5 Special Play Miscellaneous Mayhem cards: Luckstone, The Phoenix, Keep it Moving, Technicality and Stubborn Determination;
     The most important card: a card explaining how to use the other cards. 


—description from the publisher

Name: Blood Bowl (2016 edition): Goblin Pitch & Dugout Set
Description:
A double-sided card Blood Bowl pitch, complete with matching dug-outs, this is the perfect place for your Goblin teams to play. One side features a slightly worse for wear grass (and mud) pitch, covered in craters and debris – it’s even sprouting mushrooms. The other side is the same pitch after an extremely heavy rainfall – it’s completely waterlogged, and some unfortunate Goblins have drowned in the craters. The dug-outs are themed to match, and feature score trackers, reserves, Knocked Out and Serious Injury boxes, Down trackers for both halves, and a re-roll tracker.

The pitch is made to the same specifications as the board included with the Blood Bowl boxed game, and includes rules for play on a waterlogged pitch.

—description from the publisher

Name: Blood Bowl (2016 edition): Elven Union Pitch & Dugout Set
Description:
A double-sided card Blood Bowl pitch, complete with matching dug-outs, this is the perfect place for your Elven Union teams to play. One side features a perfectly manicured grass pitch with an Elven Union symbol delicately mown into the centre, the other is a frozen field entirely covered in ice by the swirling winds of magic. The dug-outs are themed to match, with opulent marble boxes and gems everywhere – they feature score trackers, reserves, Knocked Out and Serious Injury boxes, Down trackers for both halves, and a re-roll tracker.

The pitch is made to the same specifications as the board included with the Blood Bowl boxed game, and includes rules for playing on a frozen pitch.

—description from the publisher

Name: Best Allies: Rules for Gaming 18th Century Battles
Description:
The 18th century in Europe saw a massive development in weapons and tactics. The musket was refined into a flintlock, smoothbore with a socket bayonet. Although accuracy was low, which limited effective fire to very short ranges, volume of fire improved considerably and units were capable of firing three and sometimes four rounds a minute. The infantryman was now capable of combining the roles of musketeer and pikeman in one. And to maximise firepower, formations became wider. The aim was to move a formation to within range of the enemy and then overwhelm them with firepower. Only rarely was a bayonet charge needed.

—description from the rulebook

Units of 3 bases represent an infantry battalion or cavalry squadron. Suggested basing sizes are given for 6, 15, and 25/28mm figures.

Players take turns activating one brigade at a time. Each brigade commander is rated as Poor, Average, or Excellent, which allows the commander to activate 1-3 groups of brigade units. After all brigades have activated, combat occurs.

The game includes army lists for various 18th century wars: Great Norther War, American Indian Wars, War of Spanish Succession, Wars Against the Turks, Jacobite Risings, Seven Years War, American War of Independence, and the French Revolutionary Wars.
Families: History: War of the Spanish Succession

Name: Turbo Words
Description:
Turbo Words is a fast paced word game for 2-4 players.

Players act simultaneously to fill individual playing boards with randomly selected lettered game tiles with the aim of creating as many words as possible.

Other game tiles force players to directly interact with each other adding to the intensity and enjoyment of the game.

The timer can also be started by any player... ensuring that the action is never allowed to slow down!

—description from the publisher

Name: Quando for grande QUERO SER…
Description:
“When I grow up, I want to be…” This has been said, is said and will be said by children everywhere. There is a time when a child starts to discover the various professions and by the influence of a familiar or by the influence of some book or movie, she will identify herself with some kind of activity that she wants to do when she grows up.

Quando for grande QUERO SER… is a board game for 2 to 5 players, with ages of 5 and up. For this game 10 professions where chosen, those usually chosen by kids when completing the phrase. Those professions are: a Pilot, a Fireman, a Chef, a Police Officer, an Astronaut, an Engineer, a Mechanic, a Doctor, a Soldier and a Farmer. Some are represented by a female drawing and others by a male drawing.

The object of the game is to put together the various profession drawings that are composed of 3 parts: Head, torso and feet. The players need to have skill, attention and a bit of luck in order to gather on the board the three parts that are needed to complete each profession drawing. Besides the different drawings, the background color for each profession is also different in order to help the younger players to identify each of the parts for each of the professions so they can easily put together the complete set.
The winner will be the one who can complete the most profession drawings.

Name: Shoudo: The Scorched Earth Game
Description:
In Shoudo, two players face off across the battlefield of the Sengoku Jidai - the Japanese civil war. The players assume control of one of four great clans - Uesugi, Mori, Tokugawa, or Shimazu - and attempt to defeat their opponent to become the Shogun.

Shoudo is a terrain-based strategy game. The board, which consists of 40 cards, is shuffled and laid out in a random 5x8 configuration at the start of each game. Each player controls 3 armies which they may use to "burn" enemy lands and attack enemy armies and castles. The first player to destroy their opponent's Daimyo castle wins the game.

To win, players must engage in combat. When attacking an enemy army or castle, combat is fought over 3 rounds. Each round, both players roll a 6-sided combat die and add the strength of their unit and its terrain bonus - the higher roll wins the round, and the first player to win 2 rounds wins the combat.

Special clan abilities, inspired by the traditional clans, affect gameplay, giving each clan a unique advantage. These abilities can give tactical advantage or greater sustainability.

—description from the designer

Name: Mythic Battles: Pantheon – Thermopylae Battlefield
Description: New double-sided map for Mythic Battles: Pantheon. One side is the new Thermopylae Battlefield, while the other side features an even larger version of Poseidon's Sea from the Poseidon expansion. This side connects with the map from that expansion to form one continuous piece of art and an extra-large map for your sea battles.

Name: Shadows of Brimstone: Ancient Horrors Enemy Pack
Description:
Tearing their way through the Void, these nightmare creatures are masses of writhing tentacles and ancient hate! Burrowing through realities, once manifested into a physical form, they lay dormant beneath the earth, sometimes for millennia; waiting with vile intent as they writhe in their hibernation. Most often, these Ancient Horrors are awakened from their dread repose by the smell of Dark Stone, or the call of some malign and eldritch being of great power, summoning evil to do its bidding.

This Enemy Pack contains everything you need to add these ancient and terrifying, creatures to your games of Shadows of Brimstone!  There are 2 Extra large Ancient Horror models included, as well as the large Enemy Record Sheet and all of the Threat Cards needed to add them to your games.

—description from the publisher

Name: Scythe: The Rise of Fenris
Description:
Empires have risen and fallen in the aftermath of the Great War, and Europa stands on the precipice of a new era. The economy is robust, morale is high, and defenses are strong. There are reports from the countryside of strange soldiers with glowing eyes, but they seem distant and harmless.

Scythe: The Rise of Fenris, the conclusion to the Scythe expansion trilogy, enables two different options for any player count (1-5 if you have Scythe; 1-7 players if you have Invaders from Afar):


     Campaign (8 games): The story of Scythe continues and concludes with an eight-episode campaign. While the campaign includes surprises, unlocks, and persistent elements, it is fully resettable and replayable.
     Modular (11 modules): Instead of—or after—the campaign, the new modules in The Rise of Fenris can be used in various combinations to cater to player preferences. These modules are compatible with all Scythe expansions, and they include a fully cooperative module.


While the exact nature of the episodes and modules will remain a mystery (most of these components are in 5 secret tuckboxes and on 6 punchboards), the components in this expansion include a detailed episodic guidebook, 13 plastic miniatures, 62 wooden tokens, 2 custom dice, 25 tiles, and 100+ cardboard tokens.

—description from the publisher
